Award.AwardTitle: Preparing to Teach Mathematics with Technology: Expanding, Transforming, & Building Community [PTMT-ETC]

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is creating teaching materials, implementing new teaching strategies, and developing undergraduate faculty expertise - all in service of preparing prospective secondary and middle school mathematics teachers to use technology effectively in their classrooms. Building on previous work to integrate preservice teachers' learning of mathematics, technology, and pedagogy in the areas of data analysis and probability (DAP) and geometry (GEO), the project investigators are well-situated to develop materials focused on algebra. Tools being used include graphing calculators, computer algebra systems, spreadsheets, dynamic programs for geometry, and dynamic statistical packages. The intellectual merit of this project lies in its recognition that while prospective mathematics teachers may have some experience in K-12 or college-level mathematics courses that employ reform-oriented pedagogy and use technology, such use of technology in their own mathematical learning is often insufficient to understand implications for teaching with these tools. Hence, the investigators are putting into place a systematic program through which preservice teachers can develop an understanding of teaching and learning that goes beyond specific technology tools. Indeed, this model for developing teacher knowledge has the potential to transform preservice teacher programs. The project is exercising broader impacts by intentionally fostering a community of faculty responsible for teaching preservice courses who are helping to test materials and implement the approaches at a variety of different institutions. Moreover, algebraic ideas are found throughout middle and high school mathematics curriculum, and courses in algebra often serve as a gatekeeper for many STEM-related careers. Thus improved algebra learning has downstream payoffs for all students who are pursuing STEM fields of study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2011-2017, the Preparing to Teach Mathematics with Technology: Expanding, Transforming, and Community Building project (PTMT-ETC) focused on improving mathematics teacher preparation by designing curricula, preparing and sustaining a community of mathematics teacher education faculty, and examining the impacts of how the curricula was transforming the preparation of mathematics teachers. The curricula uses dynamic mathematics technologies such as The Geometer’s Sketchpad, GeoGebra, Fathom, and TinkerPlots to engage prospective mathematics teachers in deepening their understandings of critical concepts in Algebra, Geometry, Data Analysis and Probability through an integrated approach that builds knowledge and skills in content, pedagogy, and technology. The materials were initially disseminated via textbooks with accompanying websites for technology and video components through a publisher at a low cost. With support from this grant, these materials were transformed to be disseminated through an open access, free, web portal. This web portal provides the curricula materials in the form of  pdf files, technology files, and embedded videos. The portal has grown to include over 430 registered users, who are predominately university faculty and other teacher professional development providers.

 

The PTMT materials have been used in at least 150 different university teacher preparation programs with over 4500 future or practicing mathematics teachers in 38 states. As a broader impact, the K-12 students of these teachers then benefit from having well-prepared mathematics teachers who can harness the power of technology to enhance the learning of mathematics. Faculty in at least 50 institutions have attended workshops held at conferences and at NC State to learn to use the signature PTMT integrated approach that blends and scaffolds the learning of mathematical content, pedagogical strategies, and technological skills. The project has created an active community of faculty committed to preparing mathematics teachers to effectively use technology. Our research on the impact of these curricula materials indicate that prospective teachers are able to make sense of and interpret students’ work with technology by examining video cases, and planning lessons that use a variety of technology tools beyond the ones used in the curricula materials. One study showed that several years after learning with the PTMT curricula materials during their undergraduate preparation, practicing mathematics teachers make informed decisions to use a variety of dynamic mathematical technologies to engage students in developing mathematical understandings, and other technology tools for classroom presentation, organization, and assessment, so that it enhances the teaching of specific learning goals. Interviews and classroom observations were used to develop several videos, and added to the free PTMT portal, that provide learning experiences for future teachers to consider how novice and more experienced mathematics teachers use technology in teaching mathematics.

 

In addition to the free high-quality web-based materials, since 2011 the faculty and graduate students associated with PTMT have contributed 7 journal articles, 5 book chapters, 3 conference proceedings, 5 dissertations/theses, and 28 conference presentations. Principal Investigators have been recognized for their outstanding contributions to undergraduate education and research in mathematics teacher education.


See website for more information http://ptmt.fi.ncsu.edu.
